vulnerability.description: Improper Privilege Management in Gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: An issue exsits in Gitea through 1.15.7, which could let a malicious user gain privileges due to client side cookies not being deleted and the session remains valid on the server side for reuse.

vulnerability.description: Reuse of one time passwords allowed in Gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: An Authentication Bypass vulnerability exists in Gitea before 1.5.0, which could let a malicious user gain privileges. If captured, the TOTP code for the 2FA can be submitted correctly more than once.

vulnerability.description: Gitea Remote Code Execution (RCE)

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Gitea before 1.5.4 allows remote code execution because it does not properly validate session IDs. This is related to session ID handling in the go-macaron/session code for Macaron.

vulnerability.description: Shell command injection in gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Gitea before 1.16.7 does not escape git fetch remote.

vulnerability.description: Gitea Missing Authorization vulnerability

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Missing Authorization in GitHub repository go-gitea/gitea prior to 1.16.4.

vulnerability.description: Arbitrary file deletion in gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: An arbitrary file deletion vulnerability in Gitea v1.16.3 allows attackers to cause a Denial of Service (DoS) via deleting the configuration file.

vulnerability.description: Gogs and Gitea SSRF Vulnerability

relatedVulnerabilities.description: An SSRF vulnerability in webhooks in Gitea through 1.5.0-rc2 and Gogs through 0.11.53 allows remote attackers to access intranet services.

vulnerability.description: Stored Cross-site Scripting in gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Stored in GitHub repository go-gitea/gitea prior to 1.16.9.

vulnerability.description: Path Traversal in Gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: The avatar middleware in Gitea before 1.13.6 allows Directory Traversal via a crafted URL.

vulnerability.description: Cross-site Scripting in Gitea

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Gitea 1.12.x and 1.13.x before 1.13.4 allows XSS via certain issue data in some situations.

vulnerability.description: Gitea erroneous repo clones

relatedVulnerabilities.description: In Gitea through 1.17.1, repo cloning can occur in the migration function.

vulnerability.description: Gitea XSS Vulnerability

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Gitea 1.7.0 and earlier is affected by: Cross Site Scripting (XSS). The impact is: Attacker is able to have victim execute arbitrary JS in browser. The component is: go-get URL generation - PR to fix: https://github.com/go-gitea/gitea/pull/5905. The attack vector is: victim must open a specifically crafted URL. The fixed version is: 1.7.1 and later.

vulnerability.description: code.gitea.io/gitea Open Redirect vulnerability

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Open Redirect in GitHub repository go-gitea/gitea prior to 1.19.4.

When curl retrieves an HTTP response, it stores the incoming headers so that
they can be accessed later via the libcurl headers API.

However, curl did not have a limit in how many or how large headers it would
accept in a response, allowing a malicious server to stream an endless series
of headers and eventually cause curl to run out of heap memory.

swift-nio-http2 vulnerable to HTTP/2 Stream Cancellation Attack

relatedVulnerabilities.description: The HTTP/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in August through October 2023.

vulnerability.description: HTTP/2 rapid reset can cause excessive work in net/http

relatedVulnerabilities.description: A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive server resource consumption. While the total number of requests is bounded by the http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting, resetting an in-progress request allows the attacker to create a new request while the existing one is still executing. With the fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now bound the number of simultaneously executing handler goroutines to the stream concurrency limit (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests arriving when at the limit (which can only happen after the client has reset an existing, in-flight request) will be queued until a handler exits. If the request queue grows too large, the server will terminate the connection. This issue is also fixed in golang.org/x/net/http2 for users manually configuring HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency limit is 250 streams (requests) per HTTP/2 connection. This value may be adjusted using the golang.org/x/net/http2 package; see the Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and the ConfigureServer function.

relatedVulnerabilities.description:
When curl retrieves an HTTP response, it stores the incoming headers so that
they can be accessed later via the libcurl headers API.

However, curl did not have a limit in how many or how large headers it would
accept in a response, allowing a malicious server to stream an endless series
of headers and eventually cause curl to run out of heap memory.
The HTTP/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in August through October 2023.
